setup.question: Which best describes the relationship between the protagonists?
answers: They work together and are able to coordinate with each other pretty well.
They're friendly but their friendship detracts from their ability to problem-solve and be productive.

Text.text: These both seem plausible. Setting to equal odds.
Our two protaganists: Click Hathaway and Marnagan are friends who coordinate well.
. They clearly have a strong relationship, even with some rather minor turmoil, coordinate effectively.
The protagonists, Irish and Click, are
, the pirate being

. They are trying to find a way to defeat Gunther and get back to earth. Though they're friendly throughout the story, and though they eventually manage to survive, many of their difficulties come from each character valiantly trying to save the other from death and blindly believing each other. For example, here, Irish believes Click (Hathaway)'s assertion that the beasts are fake, but is attacked by a real one:
, and gets badly hurt.
he says--their friendship actually inhibits much of their progress.

B's evidence seems marginally more compelling, since they claim that there is at least one instance in which their beliefs cause problems for the other. A's evidence doesn't really move me on their ability to coordinate, though if A can cite more clear evidence of their general cooperation (rather than just saying nice things about each other?) I will be moved by that.

Is it the case that this is a more pervasive phenomenon? I'd also like to hear A's view on this incident.

To clarify these characters (as per the story name Monster Maker) are fighting for their lives from these large beasts, which they originally perceive to be real, that is until Click uses his camera and realizes they aren't real but just some sort of delusion inflected onto them. 
Anyway, I can prove that these characters coordinate well.

First they are clearly coordinated as per this ev:

. There's also literally no point in the story where they don't come out on top which proves they can problem solve effectively.
the only ev B brings is when Marnagan thinks the monster is real because he's delusional - no conflict

The question at hand is not whether or not the MCs are friends, or whether they survive in the end (which I already made clear, they do); it's about whether their friendship helps them problem-solve or detracts from it. 

The incident with the beasts I explained in my last speech is one of, if not *the* most important events in the story that's used as exposition of the MCs relationship and ability to work with one another. Again, it's the fact that they are worried about one another that detracts from their problem-solving. Here:
Hathaway near-sacrifices himself for his friend, which was actually *counter*-productive.

I'm still more convinced by B here, since they are providing a clear thesis for what the potential harm is: that they're overly concerned with one another's safety, and this causes them to do things less than optimally.

However: B, can you say more about "problem-solving" and "productivity"? It seems like the main issues is that they might make bad decisions, but that's not necessarily evidence of the two main contentions you need to establish.

A: Can you give textual evidence of "coordination"? So far you've just given evidence of platitudes which amount to friendship, which isn't really under debate.

B just did my job for me - Click Hathaway covering his friend in a sacrifical act is PEAK coordination. 
B won't give you evidence about detraction because its not there - just because they have some conflict in their communication does not prove they can't coordinate. Because they CAN.
To reiterate: Hathaway's near-sacrifice was not good coordination--it got in the way, as shown by Irish telling him
and

. There's no use in Hathaway jumping on him to save him; it was counter-productive.

Judge, further to your question about decisions vs. problem-solving, the passage I've cited is them escaping the cave to find a way to fix their probelms with oxygen supply and also being stuck on a planet--this is the problem-solving the question is referring to.

The fact that they also argued, for ex, about who would face the beasts bc they each wanted it to be themself wasted valuable time & oxygen:

I'm going to resolve for B here. There's not really any debate happening about the facts on the ground, so to speak, but over their interpretation. B contends that their friendship is causing them to make bad decisions, including some which annoy each other. This is textually supported, and I'm unconvinced by A's argument that these are all things which show they can coordinate. The sacrificial part, for instance, is only helpful if it's necessary, which it seems like it isn't.
Seems both answers are pretty similar, looking forward to a lot of clash to determine my vote
Leaning A because the example that B gives seems to be rather minor.
B's last ev was decisive for me, and proved that they are beyond work buddies and that their friendship negatively affects their ability to be productive

answers.reason for outcome: Honestly, I'm very surprised by this. I found the dishonest debater's claims that the actions taken by the friends were counter productive, and A didn't seem to have a good retort to this.
pretty convoluted arguing on my part and honest debater didn't really refute that much... also story was unclear and answer was debatable.
Judge got very B-biased for no reason. but in their defense i thought i was the dishonest position.
B's evidence was really decisive for me, as well as the fact that A didn't refute that Marnagan's act of sacrifice/friendship was counter-productive.
